prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The estimates of brightness temperatures of target lines are described in Section 1.5 in the Scientific Justification and summarize in Table 2. The requested sensitivities of 0.4 K (band 6) and 0.25 K (band 7) for the LMC targets enable at least 10-sigma detections of target lines, while the sensitivities of 0.35 K (band 6) and 0.2 K (band 7)for the SMC target enable at least 3-sigma detections. For weak lines (CH3OH at 241.77 GHz and SO2 at 241.62 GHz) of the SMC target, we average more channels to increase S/N.
A typical line width of high-mass star-forming cores is ~7 mk/s. We used the bandwidth of 2 km/s to calculate the sensitivity, which is sufficient for detections of target lines. Detailed analysis of the spectral line profile is beyond the scope of this project.

We use two spectral setups (band 6 and 7) to observe multiple lines with different J-value for multitransitional lines analysis.
A typical line width of high-mass star-forming cores is ~7 km/s. We thus request the spectral resolution of 1-2 km/s for line detections. Detailed analysis of spectral profiles is beyond the scope of this proposal.
We estimate the source velocity of 250 km/s for the LMC and 120 km/s for the SMC based on our previous spectral line observations of the LMC/SMC with Mopra. A slight change of sky frequencies of target lines does not affect observation feasibility since the requested bandwidth is wide enough.

A typical size of high-mass star-forming cores is 0.1 pc. This corresponds to 0.4 arcseconds at the distance of the LMC (50 kpc) and 0.35 arcseconds at the SMC (60 kpc). Thus we request the spatial resolution of 0.4 and 0.35 arcseconds for LMC and SMC targets, respectively. Since the targets are almost a point source, we do not need to use the ACA.
We observe five targets in total. Four LMC targets are close enough on the sky, and required sensitivity and resolution are the same. Thus we specify the observing positions of each target by the offset value relative to the target No.1 (ST2). The target positions are accurately measured based on infrared imaging data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Interstellar chemistry in low metallicity environments is crucial to understand chemical processes in the past universe. The Large and Small Magellanic Clouds are excellent targets to study chemical processes in low metallicity thanks to their proximity and metal-poor environments. Prior to this proposal, we conducted spectral line surveys toward giant moleculer clouds in the LMC with single-dish telescopes Mopra and ASTE. As a result, we found that molecular clouds in the LMC experience chemical processes different from those in our Galaxy. However, the beam size of single-dish telescopes (5-10 pc at the LMC) is too large to resolve internal structures of GMCs, and emission from star-forming cores (~0.1 pc), which reflect the chemical compositions of molecular gas associated with newly formed stars, is almost diluted out. Here we propose spectral line observations toward embedded high-mass YSOs in the LMC and the SMC to unveil the impact of low metallicity environments on chemistry of star-forming molecular cloud cores. This proposal should elucidate a possible link between chemical properties of dense molecular gas and metallicity of the parent galaxy.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
